turn.0: ELI5: If "Nazi" stands for "National Socialist" and Hitler's Germany was a completely centralised, regulated and authoritarian state, then why is the Nazi Party considered to be far-right?
turn.1: Because you can have right wing authoritarianism and left wing authoritarianism.
turn.2: Economically speaking, Hitler's Nazi party was left of centre. (Regulation vs. Open Market)
turn.3: Regulation doesn't necessarily entail left wing, they outlawed labor unions and striking.  Left wing ideologies generally favor workers rights over those of capital owners.
turn.4: Interesting. So it's sort of policy combined with idealogy that places it in its place. I was too rigid in my understanding. I just looked at policy alone.
turn.5: You were looking at just economic policy, there are policies other than economic - namely social and foreign.  However, even in their economic policy the Nazi party wasn't left of center in most areas.
